2026 WILL BE THE YEAR OF SPACE

Orbital Launch (access to space)
‚Ä¢ $SPACEX enables low-cost, high-cadence launch that underpins the entire ecosystem
‚Ä¢ $RKLB provides dedicated launch and integrated space services for small and mid-size missions
‚Ä¢ $FLY, $SPCE, $ULA expand launch capacity across different mission profiles

Satellite Operators (demand layer)
‚Ä¢ $PL, $BKYS supply earth-observation & intelligence data
‚Ä¢ $AMZN (Project Kuiper) builds global broadband infrastructure in LEO
‚Ä¢ $ASTS building the communications layer that monetizes space-based connectivity
‚Ä¢ $VSAT, $SPIR, $SATL support maritime, aviation & specialized connectivity
‚Ä¢ $TSAT, $GSAT deliver satellite communications & spectrum-driven services

Space Infrastructure (on-orbit systems & services)
‚Ä¢ $LUNR provides lunar & deep-space mission infrastructure
‚Ä¢ $VOYG supports spacecraft services & mission operations
‚Ä¢ $MNTS handles in-space logistics, transport & orbital services

Manufacturing & Supply (industrial backbone)
‚Ä¢ $LMT, $NOC, $RTX, $BA build spacecraft, launch systems & national-security platforms
‚Ä¢ $BWXT supplies nuclear components critical to space & defense systems
‚Ä¢ $LHX, $TDY, $HON deliver avionics, sensors & mission-critical hardware
‚Ä¢ $RDW, $KULR support space-grade materials, robotics & thermal systems
‚Ä¢ $KTOS, $ESLT enable defense-aligned space & autonomous systems

$MU announced it will officially break ground on its $100B New York megafab on January 16.

This is what onshoring memory actually looks like.

WHY THE $ASTS DOWNGRADE IS WRONG

1. Distribution is already solved
AST doesn‚Äôt need to acquire users since they come through carriers like $T, $VZ, Vodafone, Rakuten and others. That‚Äôs billions of subscribers already embedded in the system so focusing on retail signups is the wrong metric when the carriers already own the customer relationship. 

2. Coverage Is the Product
AST makes money by filling coverage gaps that networks can‚Äôt reach like roaming uplift, emergency access, etc. There is no hardware to subsidize, no dishes to ship and no consumer marketing funnel to fund so applying a consumer telecom playbook here leads to the wrong conclusions.

3. AST Isn't Starlink
Starlink is built like an internet company that sells directly to consumers starting with basic service and slowly adding more features. AST is built to plug directly into existing 4G and 5G networks so phones can make calls, stream video & use data without any new hardware. Both approaches can work but AST is aiming to be the satellite system mobile carriers use behind the scenes instead of sending their customers to Elon.

The AST downgrade follows a familiar sell-side pattern with frontier infrastructure names where they anchor on near-term revenue optics and treating AST  like a consumer-facing telecom which is wrong. AST is not a retail business and never intends to be but is a wholesale infrastructure layer that sells coverage to mobile network operators.

ADP private payrolls rose 41K in December below expectations for 50K.

$OKLO signed a deal with the U.S. DoE to build and run a pilot nuclear facility that produces specialized radioactive materials.

The deal expands Oklo‚Äôs role beyond power generation into nuclear materials production.

Looking back at my April 3, 2024 note, I clearly missed a  0. 

$RKLB is already up ~22x from those levels two years later  üòÖ

Two years ago, I made $RKLB 16% of my growth portfolio when it was under $4 & took a lot of heat for it since most people viewed it only through a SpaceX lens.

That conviction was dismissed as inexperience as if I were too young to understand ‚Äúreal risk.‚Äù

Turns out the real risk was sitting out the biggest secular trade of our generation.

$MU today:
‚Ä¢ $344/share

A decade ago memory was treated as a purely cyclical business tied to PCs & smartphones. Today, AI has turned memory into a structural bottleneck that data centers, edge devices, autonomy & agentic systems all require orders of magnitude more DRAM & bandwidth than prior cycles.

As $NVDA CEO Jensen Huang just said this week, AI is becoming memory-first as models & agents ‚Äúthink‚Äù longer & retain more context. 

In that world, Micron at $500 isn‚Äôt hard to see.

$NVDA CEO Jensen Huang said AI‚Äôs biggest bottleneck is energy where compute, cooling & networking can be sourced in months but power takes years.

That gap forces massive investment into generation & grid infrastructure creating decade-long tailwinds for the entire power ecosystem

10 names to watch:
‚Ä¢ $NNE grid buildout
‚Ä¢ $VST grid generation
‚Ä¢ $CCJ uranium supply
‚Ä¢ $VRT power & cooling
‚Ä¢ $CEG nuclear baseload
‚Ä¢ $OKLO micro-nuclear edge
‚Ä¢ $LEU enriched uranium fuel
‚Ä¢ $EOSE long-duration storage
‚Ä¢ $GEV grid equipment & power hardware
‚Ä¢ $UUUU domestic uranium & enrichment

$GOOGL Gemini moved from 6% to 22% of GenAI web traffic in a year while ChatGPT dropped from 87% to 65% which to me shows user changing behavior.

Gemini shows up where questions already live inside Search, Chrome, Android & Workspace so new AI usage does not require a new habit, a new app or a new URL but it simply shows up.

2026 WILL BE THE YEAR OF AI MEMORY

‚Ä¢ $MU supplies the DRAM & HBM next to GPUs that let AI think longer & hold more context.
‚Ä¢ $SNDK, $STX, $WDC store massive AI datasets & model files so training and inference can scale.
‚Ä¢ $PSTG, $NTAP turn raw memory & disks into reliable storage systems enterprises actually run AI on.
‚Ä¢ $LRCX, $AMAT build the equipment that makes advanced memory like DRAM, HBM & NAND possible.
‚Ä¢ $MRVL, $RMBS, $SIMO design the controllers that control how fast data moves between GPUs & memory.
